author: Abc Wide Bay
title: Travelling Australia with kids in the Caravan of Crazy - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Bundaberg 4670 
It is an adventure commonly associated with grey nomads — hitching a caravan to the back of the vehicle and setting off on a tour around the country. 
But more people of much younger ages are also choosing to set off, throwing in the added complication of travelling around Australia with children in tow. 
The Willett family from Bundaberg — mum Tania, dad Ben and their four kids aged under 13 — have spent 18 months visiting every state and territory. 
A six-month trip in 2007 gave them the travel bug, and in 2010 they knew they wanted to travel for longer so they put together a five-year plan. Photo: The Willett family are Tania, Ben, Veda, Hendrix, River, Astrid, and Betty the staffy. (Supplied: Tania Willett) 
The family went on the hunt for a caravan to suit their needs, eventually finding a 1973 Viscount that had seen better days, for $300. 
Three years of renovations turned it from a worn-out shell to a self-sufficient foldaway van, called the Caravan of Crazy. 
"We knew in the new van everything had to have its place. We didn't want anything on the ground or on the beds or just taking up space," Ms Willett said. 
"Building our own van enabled us to put in a four-bunk back bedroom for the kids, a dining booth and a full kitchen with an oven, a 180-litre fridge and a full-size double bed." Photo: All of the Willett children are home-schooled, meaning there was no getting out of schoolwork on the road. (Supplied: Tania Willett) Plenty of places to stop and stay forever 
The family set off south from Bundaberg heading for Tasmania, although debate rages in the caravanning community as to which way to circle the continent — clockwise or anticlockwise? 
"It depends what time of the year you leave and where you leave from," Ms Willett said. 
"We left in June so we headed south in winter which didn't make sense to a lot of people. 
"We travelled south first into Tassie, then we came back to the mainland, up through the centre and then west and anticlockwise around the WA coast. 
"You also have to take into consideration headwinds, because travelling west across the Nullarbor during certain times of the year will double or triple your fuel consumption." Photo: The wide open road is a lure to many who have the travel bug. (Supplied: Tania Willett) 
Ms Willett said along the way there were many places they could have stopped and stayed forever. 
The family stopped in for eight weeks at Alice Springs, mostly due to meeting like-minded families travelling the same way. 
"You can never anticipate what a place is going to be like. Some places you pull up and you think it's going to be great but you hop into bed and you leave the next day," she said. 
"Then you get to places like Alice Springs and you meet some other people and you say 'Would you mind looking after our kids for a couple of hours?' and they're more than happy to do that. 
"Then you return the favour. Out on the road we're all in the same boat." Photo: The children look on as Ms Willett investigates a friendly lizard. (Supplied: Tania Willett) Planning to travel Australia with kids 
According to Tourism Research Australia data, 33.1 million nights were spent in caravan parks or camping grounds for the year ending September 2016. 
Adult couples retained the largest market share in caravan and camping when it came to nights away, with 19.1 million nights, and 11.1 million nights were spent camping by parents and children, an increase of 12 per cent. Photo: Ms Willett says the children were happy as long as the sun was shining. (Supplied: Tania Willett) 
So with more people setting off on a journey around the country, Ms Willett said the best advice was simple — just get out there. 
"The only regrets you'll have is not doing it sooner. It can be really scary but if you're not doing something scary then life is just boring, isn't it?" she said. 
A big challenge for the Willett parents was finding time to be a couple. 
"We would try and get a little break in the evenings. We'd say 'You guys can watch a movie' … we can just sit outside and be alone, have a drink, have a chat and plan the next leg of the trip," Ms Willett said. 
She said she was surprised by how many other families were doing the same thing. 
"We thought we were going to be the only ones out there. Surely nobody else is this crazy?" she said. Photo: The family often hooked up with other like-minded families for fun and support. (Supplied: Tania Willett) 
"Once you get out there, you realise there are so many other people on the road. 
"We met a few families that we travelled on and off with for six months continuously, because our kids got on so well and we were going in the same direction. 
"There are a few social media groups that are centralised around travelling families, so if you're interested just search one up, have a look and you'll see how many people are doing it — it's amazing."
